_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ONEOK NORTH SYSTEM, L.L.C. (ONS)
MORRIS STORAGE AND TERMINAL
Morris, Illinois

INTRODUCTION AND POLICIES

ONEOK North System, L.L.C. (ONS) is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations. ONS management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of the Environmental Health and Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators.  

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan (RMP) is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event an accidental release should occur, the five-year accident history of the facility, and planned changes to improve safety at the facility.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Morris Storage and Terminal is owned and operated by ONS. At the facility, ethane/propane mix (EP Mix) is stored in an underground storage cavern until it is transferred, via pipeline, to the customer. Butanes, natural gasoline, and propane are received via pipeline and stored in above ground storage tanks until they are loaded on trucks for distribution to customers. Ethyl mercaptan is used as an odorant for propane and is stored at the facility and injected into truck trailers during propane loading. The Risk Management Program (RMP) substances stored at the facility are normal butane, isobutane, propane, ethyl mercaptan, and two flammable mixtures. The flammable mixtures are EP Mix, containing ethane and propane; and natural gasoline, containing pentane and other non-RMP hydrocarbons. No RMP toxic substances are present at the facility. The facility is classified as Program Level 3 under the regulation. 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The a

ccidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facility are part of the high standards striven for by ONS. These high standards include:
-	Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulations.
-	Operating and maintaining the assets in such a manner that unintentional releases are minimized.
-	Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.
-	Correcting non-compliance found during regular audits of the facility.
 
PREVENTION PROGRAM

Morris Storage and Terminal is operating under the guidelines of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program. Ongoing analysis of the potential hazards of the process, detailed training of employees, and emphasis on safety have helped avoid any serious chemical release accidents over the last 5 years. Part of this program has also involved identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases. A few examples of the prevention features implemented at this facility include:
?	Hazardous atmosphere monitors (HAM) have been installed at the facility, which will shutdown power to the loading facility upon a positive reading.
?	Manual emergency shutdown (ESD) buttons have been installed at the facility in order to shut down the entire facility during emergency situations.
?	Fire eyes have been installed at the terminal in various locations to warn of a fire at the facility.
?	A continuous flare is tied into critical equipment to minimize the possibility of releases.
?	The facility is manned 24 hours per day, which improves response time in the event of a release.
?	The Tulsa Control Center can detect high and low pressure on the pipeline and storage vessels as well as levels on storage vessels, and remotely close inlet and outlet valves, if necessary.
?	All drivers are provided with driver loading safet

y training and a driver loading handbook.
The facility is equipped with key card access, ensuring that only trained drivers conduct loading operations.
?	Security cameras are installed for monitoring security and operational surveillance.
?	Key card access is installed to limit access to the facility.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
	
No incident resulting in onsite injuries, death or property damage or offsite impacts from a hydrocarbon release has occurred at the facility within the last five years. 
	
EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
	
The facility will continue to conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary with the Morris Fire Department. The Operations Supervisor is responsible for coordinating emergency actions. A specific Emergency Response Plan for the facility is in place and that plan has been coordinated with local officials, along with evacuation procedures, periodic drilling, and training. The Emergency Response Program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.
	
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
	
Compliance with the RMP Prevention Program, coupled with the Environmental Health and Safety Management Systems, forms the framework for continuous safety improvement. Some of the key components of the safety program are:
-	The Management of Change provisions ensure that the potential safety and health impacts of any change made to process chemicals, technology, equipment, or procedures are considered.
-	The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) methods used to perform Hazard Reviews serve as a tool to ensure timely evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in safety standards.
-	The Process Safety Information and Maintenance provisions ensure that process equipment and   instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed, and maintained in such a manner as to minimize the risk of

hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program.

Specific actions that will be taken in the future to improve the level of safety at the facility include:
-	Internal and third-party compliance audits will ensure that the level of safety protection at the facility is periodically evaluated for improvements.
-	An ongoing dialogue with the Grundy County Emergency Management Director or his designate will ensure a constant state of readiness to respond to any potential emergencies, as well to implement improvements as the need develops. 

All interested citizens or community organizations are encouraged to contact the Grundy County Emergency Management Director for the latest information on emergency response for the county. The facility coordinates its response capabilities and personnel with those of the county on an ongoing basis.
